headline: This Should Be V.R.’s Moment. Why Is It Still So Niche?
text: I have wanted to love virtual reality for a really long time.

headline: Top E.U. Diplomat Says Disinformation Report Was Not Watered Down for China
text: BRUSSELS — Facing pointed criticism from lawmakers on Thursday, the European Union’s top diplomat denied that Chinese officials had pressured his team to soften language in a recent report on disinformation about the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Quarantini Anyone? When Everyday Drinking Becomes a Problem
text: As weeks in lockdown pile up, what started out as a way to unwind may start to feel like an unexpectedly stubborn habit.

headline: Frustrated by Crowds, Coastal States Weigh What to Do About Beaches
text: MIAMI — The salty breeze and ocean waves have beckoned stir-crazy residents of the coast back to their beloved beaches, social distancing norms be damned.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Immigration Shifts
text: This graph and map, showing immigrants’ share of the U. S. population, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: Latest Tactic to Push Migrants From Europe? A Private, Clandestine Fleet
text: With the onset of the coronavirus, Malta announced that it was too overwhelmed to rescue migrants making the precarious crossing of the Mediterranean Sea, where the tiny island nation has been on the front line of the maritime migration route over the past decade.

headline: Oh, Rats! Finally Moving Your Car? You May Get a Surprise.
text: You might want to make sure there’s not a rat living (or recently dead) in your car’s engine.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: After months of imposing social distancing, a few governments are now reporting remarkable milestones: recording zero new domestically transmitted coronavirus cases, or no new cases at all.

headline: Valentina Blackhorse, Navajo Pageant Winner With Dreams, Dies at 28
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Valentina Blackhorse, the winner of one pageant after another in the Navajo Nation, was known for helping others. When the coronavirus began tearing across her reservation, she counseled family members to stay home, wash their hands and wear masks.

headline: The Hollywood Reporter Names a New Top Editor
text: The Hollywood Reporter has a new boss.

headline: Now Is as Good a Time as Any to Start a Family
text: I had a carefully laid out plan. On June 26, we would get married. Then we would begin trying to have a baby. If we were lucky, I would get pregnant sometime before we took up our new jobs in the fall, my husband in Jerusalem and me in Philadelphia, on a one-year academic fellowship. I would visit him for Christmas, and he would come for the final months of my pregnancy and the birth. I would use this time to write my book and I would join him in Jerusalem a year later, when I would begin a philosophy professorship, baby in tow.

headline: Get Ready for the Global Fight Over Vaccines
text: All the world agrees: We need a vaccine for the coronavirus. But as soon as we get one, it’s going to open up a geopolitical can of worms.

headline: What Students Are Saying About ‘Life by the Numbers,’ Accents and Pandemic Protests
text: For this week’s roundup of student comments on our writing prompts, we asked teenagers to share stories about their current lives using numbers, explain what their regional accent means to them and share their thoughts on protesting during a pandemic.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: The New York Times Summer Reading Contest
text: Every year since 2010 The Learning Network has invited teenagers around the world to add The New York Times to their summer reading lists and, so far, over 60,000 have.

headline: Virus Pushes the Bang on a Can Marathon Online
text: It was already going to be a year of transformation for the beloved Bang on a Can Marathon. A New York new-music institution since 1987, the annual event was set to expand into a new three-day festival, Long Play, spread over several Brooklyn performance spaces.

headline: ‘We Ran Out of Space’: Bodies Pile Up as N.Y. Struggles to Bury Its Dead
text: The 40-foot trailer has been there for weeks, parked outside the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home in Queens. Its refrigerator hums in an alley next to a check-cashing establishment. Thirty-six bodies, one atop the other, are stacked on shelves inside.

headline: Tim Brooke-Taylor, a Mainstay of British Comedy, Dies at 79
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Coronavirus Could Rewrite the Rules for Silicon Valley
text: On Thursday, Amazon reported blockbuster first-quarter sales. This week Microsoft, Facebook and Google showed robust gains of their own. Supply chain disruptions and slowing ad revenue have put little dent in these cash-rich giants that, together with Apple, account for 20 percent of the S&P 500 index. Amid the biggest economic crisis since the Great Depression, Big Tech is roaring ahead.

headline: Billions in Clean Energy Loans Go Unused as Coronavirus Ravages Economy
text: WASHINGTON — As the government struggles to keep businesses afloat through the pandemic, the Trump administration is sitting on about $43 billion in low-interest loans for clean energy projects, and critics are accusing the Energy Department of partisan opposition to disbursing the funds.

headline: Three: Mirror Image
text: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Spotify

headline: How Lobbyists Robbed Small Business Relief Loans
text: As the unemployment rate threatens to surge toward 20 percent, billionaires and corporations clearly aren’t the ones hurting the most from the economic shock caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. But they are the ones who can afford to write super PAC checks and hire lobbyists. And that has allowed them to shape aspects of Congress’ $2 trillion relief package in their favor.

headline: Biden Will Address Tara Reade’s Allegation on MSNBC on Friday
text: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. will publicly address an allegation of sexual assault for the first time in an appearance on morning television on Friday, after weeks of silence on the issue that had prompted frustration from Democrats and attacks from Republicans seeking to weaken him for a general election contest against President Trump.

headline: Local journalism helps tell the full story
text: Local journalism is in crisis and at risk of disappearing. These vital resources are critical to the safety, security and knowledge of our communities, never more so than in these difficult times. On World Press Freedom Day and every day, we encourage you to find a local news organization you trust and support it.

headline: Andy Dalton Joins Crowded N.F.L. Free Agent Pool
text: The Cincinnati Bengals cut quarterback Andy Dalton on Thursday one week after drafting his replacement, Joe Burrow of Louisiana State, with the first overall pick. Dalton spent nine seasons as their starter and will now head into a free agent market that is already crowded with talent and offers very few landing spots for veteran passers.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: As Workers Fall Ill, U.S. Presses Mexico to Keep American-Owned Plants Open
text: MEXICO CITY — The Trump administration and major U.S. manufacturers have successfully pressured Mexico to keep factories that supply the United States operating during the coronavirus pandemic, even as outbreaks erupt and waves of cases and deaths sweep the companies.

headline: Sister Patricia McGowan, Dedicated Teacher, Dies at 80
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Willie Levi, 73, Dies; He Escaped a Life of Servitude
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Crashing Economy, Rising Stocks: What’s Going On?
text: The economic news has been terrible. Never mind Wednesday’s G.D.P. report for the first quarter. An economy contracting at an annual rate of almost 5 percent would have been considered very bad in normal times, but this report only captured the first few drops of a torrential downpour. More timely data show an economy falling off a cliff. The Congressional Budget Office is projecting an unemployment rate of 16 percent later this year, and that may well be an underestimate.

headline: Lockdown TV: Netflix Dominates, News Surges and Bea Arthur Is Still Golden
text: To get through the stuck-at-home days of the coronavirus pandemic, Americans have spent significantly more time than usual in front of the TV, gorging on streaming shows, news programs, old sitcoms and video games. But new data shows that, little by little, they have started to wean themselves from their favorite lockdown diversion.

headline: Idris Bey, an N.Y.C. Emergency Worker, Dies at 60
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: There May Be a Dangerous Shortcut to a Coronavirus Vaccine
text: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Reopening, Joe Biden, Antarctica: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why the Trump Ploy Stopped Working
text: Even in a pandemic there are weavers and rippers. The weavers try to spiritually hold each other so we can get through this together. The rippers, from Donald Trump on down, see everything through the prism of politics and still emphasize division. For the rippers on left and right, politics is a war that gives life meaning.

headline: Who Should Wear Masks on Planes? More Airlines Say Everyone
text: After flight attendants and pilots criticized them for not doing more to protect employees, large airlines in the United States and around the world announced this week that they would require their crews and passengers to wear masks.

headline: Former Honduras Police Chief Charged With Drug Offenses
text: A former police chief in Honduras was charged Thursday in federal court in New York with helping to ship tons of cocaine into the United States at the behest of the Honduran president and his brother.

headline: Germano Celant, Curator Behind Italy’s Arte Povera, Dies at 79
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Pence Visits Ventilator Plant in Indiana, This Time Wearing a Mask
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence was photographed on Thursday wearing a mask while visiting a General Motors plant in Indiana in what appeared to be a tacit acknowledgment of the criticism he has received for traveling the country without one.

headline: Writing Rich Reading Responses: Participating in Our Summer Contest
text: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: Apple’s First-Quarter Sales Are Up Despite Coronavirus Slowdown
text: The global economy is showing signs of collapse, yet Apple said that its sales continued to rise and that it was buying back another $50 billion in stock.

headline: Unit 7: Independent Reading and Writing
text: Welcome to our seventh and final writing unit of the school year. Below, you will find a description of each element and an invitation to put them together to help guide your students to learn on their own now, during the summer, or even in the fall when a new school year — whatever it may look like — begins.

headline: Amazon Sells More, but Warns of Much Higher Costs Ahead
text: SEATTLE — Online shopping during the coronavirus pandemic drove sales at Amazon far higher, the company said on Thursday. But the cost to deliver those products, and to keep its workers safe, is taking a big bite out of the company’s profits.

headline: Trump Attacks Flynn Inquiry Amid New Revelations on F.B.I.
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump revived his attacks on law enforcement on Thursday as a pair of former advisers, Roger J. Stone Jr. and Michael T. Flynn, renewed their fights against their criminal convictions.

headline: After Decades of Service, Five Nuns Die as Virus Sweeps Through Convent
text: CHICAGO — Our Lady of the Angels Convent was designed as a haven of peace and prayer in a suburb of Milwaukee, a place where aging, frail nuns could rest after spending their lives taking care of others.

headline: Amid a Rising Death Toll, Trump Leaves the Grieving to Others
text: WASHINGTON — One morning this week, President Trump called food sector executives. That afternoon, he met with corporate leaders at the White House. The day before, he paraded small-business owners in the East Room, and the day before that, he showcased executives from retail giants like Walgreens and Walmart in the Rose Garden.

headline: Republicans, It’s Too Late to Back Away From Trump
text: As the coronavirus pandemic creeps deeper into the election cycle, President’s Trump campaign team has a message for Republican lawmakers: Don’t even think about trying to socially distance yourself from the president’s handling of the crisis.

headline: In a Victory for Women in Sudan, Female Genital Mutilation Is Outlawed
text: CAIRO — Sudan’s new government has outlawed the practice of female genital mutilation, a move hailed as a major victory by women’s rights campaigners in a country where the often dangerous practice is widespread.

headline: Democrats Assail McConnell for Bringing Senate Back Amid Pandemic
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats assailed Senator Mitch McConnell on Thursday for insisting on bringing the Senate back to Washington in the thick of the coronavirus pandemic, saying it could imperil not only senators and their aides, but also large numbers of low-level employees, including racial minorities at higher risk of infection and death from Covid-19.

headline: In a Crisis, True Leaders Stand Out
text: Leadership may be hard to define, but in times of crisis it is easy to identify. As the pandemic has spread fear, disease and death, national leaders across the globe have been severely tested. Some have fallen short, sometimes dismally, but there are also those leaders who have risen to the moment, demonstrating resolve, courage, empathy, respect for science and elemental decency, and thereby dulling the impact of the disease on their people.

headline: Scrambling the Political Divide: ‘No Normal Recession’
text: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Peter Hunt, Who Directed the Broadway Hit ‘1776,’ Dies at 81
text: Peter H. Hunt, who had a triumphant success with his directorial debut on Broadway, the musical “1776,” which ran for almost three years and won the Tony Award for best musical, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.
